column2: My dear blind daughter, hear me and forgive me.

column2: The world you live in, heart of mine, doesn't exist as I have represented it.

column2: The eyes you have trusted in have been false to you."

column2: She turned her wonder-stricken face towards him still; but drew back, and clung closer to her friend.
column3: She turned her wonder stricken face towards him still; but drew back, and clung closer to her friend.

column2: Your road in life was rough, my poor one, said Caleb, "and I meant to smooth it for you.
column3: Your road in life was rough, my poor one, said Caleb, "and I meant to smooth it for you.

column2: I have altered objects, changed the characters of people, invented many things that never have been, to make you happier. I have had concealments from you, put deceptions on you, God forgive me! and surrounded you with fancies."
column3: I have altered objects, changed the characters of people, invented many things that never have been, to make you happier. I have had concealments from you, put deceptions on you, God forgive me! and surrounded you with fancies."

column2: But living people are not fancies? she said hurriedly, and turning very pale, and still retiring from him.
column3: But living people are not fancies? she said hurriedly, and turning very pale, and still retiring from him.

column2: You can't change them.

column2: I have done so, Bertha, pleaded Caleb.

column3: There is one person that you know, my dove----

column2: The marriage that takes place to-day, said Caleb, "is with a stern, sordid, grinding man.

column2: Oh, why, cried the Blind Girl, tortured, as it seemed, almost beyond endurance, "why did you ever do this?
column3: Oh, why, cried the Blind Girl, tortured, as it seemed, almost beyond endurance, "why did you ever do this?

column2: Why did you ever fill my heart so full, and then come in like Death, and tear away the objects of my love? O Heaven, how blind I am!
column3: Why did you ever fill my heart so full, and then come in like Death, and tear away the objects of my love? O Heaven, how blind I am!

column2: How helpless and alone!"

column2: Her afflicted father hung his head, and offered no reply but in his penitence and sorrow.
column3: Her afflicted father hung his head, and offered no reply but in his penitence and sorrow.

column2: She had been but a short time in this passion of regret when the Cricket on the Hearth, unheard by all but her, began to chirp.

column2: Not merrily, but in a low, faint, sorrowing way.

column3: It was so mournful, that her tears began to flow; and, when the Presence which had been beside the Carrier all night, appeared behind her, pointing to her father, they fell down like rain.

column2: She heard the Cricket-voice more plainly soon, and was conscious, through her blindness, of the Presence hovering about her father.
column3: She heard the Cricket voice more plainly soon, and was conscious, through her blindness, of the Presence hovering about her father.

column2: Mary, said the Blind Girl, "tell me what my home is.
column3: Mary, said the Blind Girl, "tell me what my home is.

column2: It is a poor place, Bertha; very poor and bare indeed.	It is a poor place, Bertha; very poor and bare indeed.

column2: The house will scarcely keep out wind and rain another winter.

column2: The Blind Girl, greatly agitated, rose, and led the Carrier's little wife aside.
column3: The Blind Girl, greatly agitated, rose, and led the Carrier's little wife aside.

column2: Those presents that I took such care of; that came almost at my wish, and were so dearly welcome to me, she said, trembling; "where did they come from?

column2: More changes than you think for may happen, though, my dear, said Dot. "Changes for the better, I mean; changes for great joy to some of us. You mustn't let them startle you too much, if any such should ever happen, and affect you.

column2: I--I--I know you have a quick ear, said Dot, placing her hand upon her heart, and evidently talking on as fast as she could, to hide its palpitating state, "because I have noticed it often, and because you were so quick to find out that strange step last night.
column3: I-I-I know you have a quick ear, said Dot, placing her hand upon her heart, and evidently talking on as fast as she could, to hide its palpitating state, "because I have noticed it often, and because you were so quick to find out that strange step last night.

column2: Though why you should have said, as I very well recollect you did say, Bertha, 'Whose step is that?' and why you should have taken any greater observation of it than of any other step, I don't know.
column3: Though why you should have said, as I very well recollect you did say, Bertha, 'Whose step is that?' and why you should have taken any greater observation of it than of any other step, I don't know.

column2: Though, as I said just now, there are great changes in the world: great changes: and we can't do better than prepare ourselves to be surprised at hardly anything."
